column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality TV and its Impact on Teenagers

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It's probably impossible to find a person who lives in a developed country who wouldn't have heard of reality shows.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: A relatively new genre of entertaining production, the reality of television quickly gained popularity among all audiences, becoming one of the most demanded and lucrative niches in the media.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It creates extremely attractive content, sometimes even addictive.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: This would be good if their audience consisted entirely of adults: adults usually have established patterns of behavior, molded perspectives, and tend to view the TV content of reality as mere entertainment.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: At the same time, a large percentage of viewers are teenagers or even children – and in this case, the global popularity of reality shows may not be as harmless after all.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Although its appearance and development is often associated in the late 1990s and with youth-oriented channels such as MTV, the history of reality television goes a little further in time.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It all began in the 1970s with the program entitled “An American Family” released into the air (ANVC).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: A series of documentaries depicting worldly and sometimes dramatic events in the life of a regular Californian family captivated the minds and hearts of millions of Americans, paving the way for hundreds of ideological successors to the show.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: The idea of a reality show is a voyeur: a group of “real people” allows cameramen, directors and other television staff to enter their homes or other everyday environments, and allows them to broadcast their lives on television.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: To make these programmes more interactive, producers often start all kinds of voting, for example, when the audience decides the fate of programme participants through online surveys or phone calls.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Rather often, even adult viewers rarely contemplate the possibility that the people they see are actors, that they follow a script, and that the plot and dynamics of the show often reflect the demands and expectations of the target audience (Screenrant).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In the case of teenagers, they tend to see behavior patterns and relationship models represented in their favorite programs as copies, especially if there are celebrities involved – and this is just one of the many problems.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In particular, reality television often shows excessive amounts of aggression; this is mainly needed to keep the audience “at their feet,” which makes them guess the results of numerous encouraged interpersonal conflicts.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: For example, programmes targeting women may promote gossip, condescension and harassment as part of women’s “normal” behaviour (The MGH Clay Center for Young Healthy Minds).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Shows aimed at men can do the same, encouraging the use of aggression or even violence as a means of resolving interpersonal conflicts and/or relationship problems.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Jealousy, inadequacy, intrigue, gossip, and verbal and emotional abuse are often false in the case of reality shows, and are meant to attract and excite the public.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: However, teens can see it as real, adopting and reproducing these patterns of behavior in real life.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: And, considering how much time a normal American teenager spends watching TV, this fact is alarming.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: An even more disturbing effect that the reality shows can have on adolescents is early sexual activity and substance use.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: “Sex sells” is a formula too efficient to be neglected in the entertainment world.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: A large number of television products promote or represent sex in one way or another.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality shows are no exception to this rule; it is not uncommon to see sexually suggestive or explicit content in such reality shows as “Ex on the Beach” or “Big Brother.” At the same time, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, teenage girls who watch such reality shows tend to see physical appeal and sexual appeal as criteria for success in real life, or even means to achieve it.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: There are also reports that adolescents who watch programs with sexual content are more likely to become pregnant at an early age.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In addition, many shows represent people under the influence of inappropriate alcohol behavior.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Some studies assume that teens who see this content may feel that it is safe for them to consume alcohol at an early age, or that they cannot be held responsible for their behaviors when they are drunk (Livestrong).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: These two combined factors generate an explosive mixture, adding to the regular hormonal storms of teenagers: Needless to say, it can make the behaviors of unpredictable teenagers even more rebellious.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In the case of some reality shows, children and adolescents can be not only spectators, but also participants.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: This is mostly true for all kinds of talent shows focused on the talents or extraordinary abilities of children.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Although it may be considered relatively harmless and many parents enjoy watching such programs together with their children, there may be negative psychological effects here as well.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In particular, according to Arundhati Swamy, family counselor and child-rearing expert, such shows can attract parents to the belief that their children should also be exceptional and talented in some area.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It's okay if a child really has a talent, and his parents don't try to benefit from it.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: However, children who so far are not extraordinary can in no way begin to experience low self-esteem, comparing themselves with the participants of television programmes.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Or, parents can start putting emotional pressure on their children because of this, and attempts to adjust to excessively high expectations can have a number of adverse effects on a child (Father's Circle).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In general, reality programmes are not affecting adolescents or children positively.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: While adults with shaped perspectives and behavior patterns often see such shows as entertainment and do not seem to be significantly affected by them, teens may adopt inappropriate behavior patterns seen on television.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: These patterns include assault and harassment, early sexual activity and substance use.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Therefore, it is advisable for teens to watch reality shows under the control of their parents, or not to see them at all.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Movement for animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The movement for animal rights, sometimes called the movement of animal liberation, animal person, or animal defense movement, is a social movement that seeks to put an end to the rigid moral and legal distinction that is established between human and non-human animals, to end the status of animals as property, and to end their use in the research, food, clothing and entertainment industries.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Terms and factions

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: All animal liberationists believe that the individual interests of non-human animals deserve recognition and protection, but the movement can be divided into two broad fields.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Animal rights advocates, or liberationists of rights, believe that these basic interests confer moral rights of some kind on animals, and/or should confer legal rights on them;[1] see, for example, Tom Regan's work.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The utilitarian liberationists, on the other hand, do not believe that animals possess moral rights, but argue, for utilitarian reasons — utilitarianism in its simplest form advocating that we base moral decisions on the greatest happiness of number — that, because animals have the ability to suffer, their suffering must be taken into account in any moral philosophy.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Excluding animals from that consideration, they argue, is a form of discrimination they call speciesism; see, for example, Peter Singer's work [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Despite these differences, the terms animal release and animal rights are generally used interchangeably.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Fractional division has also been characterized as that between the reformist or dominant faction and the radical abolitionist and direct action factions.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The main faction is largely professionalized and focuses on soliciting donations and obtaining media representation.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This approach to resource mobilization, sought through the alignment of the framework with the dominant cultural frameworks, leads to a commitment to the objectives.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Actors of the reformist movement diagnose the problem as a problem of non-human animal abuse, offer a prognosis that includes welfare reform and employ frameworks of action that include moral shocks.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It has been observed that the power of the animal rights movement in the United States is centralized in professionalized non-profit organizations that prefer moderate welfare reform objectives and tend to be isomorphic [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The abolitionist faction diagnoses the problem as one of non-human animal use, offers a prognosis that includes vegan extension, and employs frameworks of action including a rational and theoretical approach.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Gary Francione, a leader in abolitionism, formed his approach in response to the traditional movement's focus on policy reform.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The members of the abolitionist faction consider policy reform counterproductive and depend on non-violent education and moral suasion in their repertoire of contests.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: They see the promotion of veganism as a low-cost means of opportunity to create an anti-species culture and pose an economic threat to the industrial complex of animal agriculture [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Direct action or militant faction includes in its repertoire damage to the property of the contest, open releases, intimidation and direct violence.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: With these, they offer a prognosis to the problem of animal use that focuses on changing society through force and fear.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Animal rights agents often reject this faction, pointing to violence as a counterproductive tactic that incites repression (e.g., the Animal Enterprise Terrorism Act) and does not question existing systems economically or politically [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The smaller factions include groups focused on the theory of animal rights based on faith and veganarchists, whose approach is characterized by a critique of capitalism on the basis that it has led to massive non-human, human and environmental exploitation [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Such fractionalization, the researchers have pointed out, is common to social movements and plays a role in sustaining their health [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: History

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The Animal Rights Movement dates back to the animal protection movement in Victorian England, which was initiated by aristocratic moral crusaders in response to the ill-treatment of urban working horses and stray dogs.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Other early influences include: Upton Sinclair's 1906 novel, which drew attention to the dark operations of slaughterhouses; Henry Salt's treatises on the non-human rights of animals; which is based on human abolitionist arguments to recognize the personality of people considered to be property; and the Alcott House of New England, a community that serves as a stopover on the Underground Railroad and which requires its residents to eat a vegan diet [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The contemporary movement is considered to have been founded in the United Kingdom in the early 1970s by a group of Oxford graduate philosophy college students, now known as Oxford Group [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The group was led by Rosalind and Stanley Godlovitch, graduate philosophy students who had recently become vegetarians.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The Godlovitches met John Harris and David Wood, also graduates in philosophy, who were soon persuaded of arguments for animal rights and became vegetarians.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The group began to actively raise the issue with the pre-eminent moral philosophers of Oxford, including Professor Richard Hare, both personally and at lectures.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: His approach was not based on sentimentalism (goodness to mute animals), but on the moral rights of animals.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Soon they developed (and borrowed) a range of powerful arguments in support of their views, so Oxford clinical psychologist Richard Ryder, who was soon to be part of the group, writes that there has rarely been such a rationally argued and intellectually well-armed cause [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It was a 1965 article by novelist Brigid Brophy in The Sunday Times that was instrumental in helping to turn the movement on.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Brophy wrote:

column1: Should we support animal rights
Should we support animal rights
column2: We use their work; we eat them and use them.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: We exploit them to serve our superstitions: while we used to sacrifice them to our gods and pluck out their bowels to foresee the future, we now sacrifice them to science, and experience about their entanglement in hope—or in mere overchance—that so we could see a little more clearly in the present [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
Should we support animal rights
column2: Philosophers found this article and were inspired by its vigorous non-sentimental polemic.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: At about the same time, Ryder wrote three letters to the Daily Telegraph in response to Brophy's arguments [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Brophy read Ryder's letters and contacted the Godlovitches and John Harris, who had begun planning a book on the subject that was also partially inspired by Brophy's controversy.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The philosophers had also gone to see Brophy about the possibility of a book of essays on the subject [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Initially they thought that a book with contributions from Brophy, Ruth Harrison, Maureen Duffy and other well-known writers might be of interest to the editors, but after an initial proposal was rejected by the first editor to approach, Giles Gordon of Victor Gollancz suggested that the work would be more viable if it included his own writing.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This was the idea that became Animals, Men and Moral' (see below).

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In 1970, Ryder coined the phrase speciesism, using it first in a privately printed brochure to describe the allocation of value to the interests of beings on the basis of their belonging to a particular species [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Ryder later became a collaborator of Animals, Men and Morals: An Inquiry into the Mal Treatment of Non-humans (1972), edited by John Harris and the Godlovitches, a work that became highly influential [ref], as did the essay by Rosalind Godlovitch Animal and Morals, published the same year.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It was in a review of Animals, Men and Morals for the New York Review of Books that Australian philosopher Peter Singer first presented his basic arguments, based on utilitarianism and drawing an explicit comparison between women's liberation and animal liberation.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: From the review came the Animal Liberation of Singer, published in 1975, now considered by many as the Bible of the movement.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Other books considered important include The case of animal rights of philosopher Tom Regan (1983); Created from animals: The moral implications of Darwinism by James Rachels (1990); Animals, property and law (1995) by legal scholar Gary Francione, Rattling the Cage: Toward Legal Rights for Animals by another legal scholar Steven M. Wise (2000); and Animal rights and moral philosophy by Julian H. Franklin (2005) [ref].

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: One option for members of the LGBT community is subrogation, and as family perceptions have become more inclusive, lesbian and gay surrogacy has become more and more common.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: While the subrogation process is generally not different for same-sex couples and individuals than for any other intended parent, there are some unique considerations that need to be taken into account.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Read on to learn more about the process, regulations, advantages and disadvantages of maternal motherhood for LGBT parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: LGBT Subrogation Process

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Subrogation is a popular option for gay men who want to be biologically connected to their children, as well as lesbian couples who cannot conceive or carry a pregnancy on their own.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: In LGBT subrogation, pregnancy is most commonly achieved using an egg donor, gestational carrier and in vitro fertilization (IVF), and the surrogacy process is essentially the same as it would be for any other anticipated parent.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: However, there are some important decisions that same-sex couples must make before starting the process:

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Decide who will be genetically related to the child.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Unlike direct substitution, in which the genetic material of both parents is often used to create an embryo, parents of the same sex must decide which sperm or egg will be used.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Some predestined parents choose to fertilize several eggs for implantation using sperm from both couples, allowing both to be the biological father of a child.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Choose a known or anonymous donor.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Although it is sometimes more convenient to work with an agency to use an anonymous sperm or egg donor, many couples and LGBT people choose to work with an identified donor to complete the subrogation process.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Predestined parents may choose to use the sperm of a couple with eggs from a close relative of the other couple, giving both parents a biological link to the child.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Once the intended parents have made these important decisions, they should be able to continue the subrogation process as would any other intended parent.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Laws on Subrogation of the Same Sex

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Each state has laws regulating subrogation, and some states do not allow or recognize subrogation contracts at all.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: This may complicate the process of legal subrogation for the intended parents and especially for parents of the same sex.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Contact a subrogacy agency to discuss the laws in your state and discover your options to complete the surrogacy process, regardless of where you live.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Pros and Cons of Surrogation for Gay Couples

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Subrogation is certainly an option for LGBT couples and individuals who are interested in adding to their families, but it is not for everyone.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Future parents must take into account all the advantages and challenges of surrogacy to determine whether surrogacy is appropriate for them.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Here are some of the most common benefits and challenges of maternal motherhood for homosexual couples:

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: PROS

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Subrogation can fulfill the lifetime dreams of future parents to complete their families.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Subrogation allows same-sex couples to have children with a biological connection with one or both parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Predestined parents have the opportunity to create meaningful long-term relationships with their substitutes.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Many substitutes are specifically interested in helping same-sex couples become parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: CONS

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Subrogation is a legally complicated process that can be even more difficult for parents of the same sex, depending on state laws.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: The cost of surrogate maternity can be high and there are fewer funding options available to the intended parents than to the adoptive parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Some LGBT couples and individuals may face discrimination or bias from some subrogation professionals, potential substitutes or donors throughout the process.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Many of the above challenges and benefits apply to heterosexual couples and individuals, as well as members of the LGBT community.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Regardless of sexual orientation, it is important for each family to consider these pros and cons of motherhood, as well as their individual circumstances, when creating a maternity plan.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Additional considerations for same-sex couples

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: In many ways, the marital status and sexual orientation of parents have no impact on their subrogation experience.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: However, there are some additional thoughts that parents should consider while embarking on their surrogacy journey.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Choosing a LGBT-friendly professional – For many of the expected parents, it is important to work with an open professional with experience in performing subrogations for same-sex couples.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: When considering possible subrogacy agencies, ask about your history of working with LGBT clients and find out if they offer advice and support specifically tailored to the same-sex surrogacy experience.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Parent Challenges – When you bring your new baby home at the end of your surrogacy trip, you will start a new chapter in your lives: parenting.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: The upbringing of children is full of infinite joys and challenges, but a challenge that especially affects parents of the same sex is the possibility of discrimination.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: While society increasingly accepts different types of families, some people still do not accept same-sex families.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Families created through subrogation may face the additional challenge of talking about the story of their child's birth.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Often, children are curious to know where they come from as they age, and explaining maternal motherhood to a young child can be a challenge.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: HIV and maternity: HIV-positive people may have healthy children through motherhood, without any risk of transmission to the baby or gestational carrier.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: The Special Assisted Reproduction Program (SPAR) has helped heterosexual and same-sex couples achieve their dreams of parenthood despite HIV.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: If you or your partner are HIV positive, talk to your professional surrogacy for more information about your surrogacy options.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Final thoughts

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Subrogation is a wonderful option for same-sex parents who are ready to expand their families.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: This path to parenthood allows members of the LGBT community to fulfill their parenting dreams while maintaining a genetic bond with their children.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Rejection of Vaccines, Compulsory Immunization and Risks of Vaccine Preventable Diseases

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccines are one of the most effective prevention tools available to doctors.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: However, the success of an immunization programme depends on the high rates of acceptance and coverage.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: There is evidence of an increase in the refusal to vaccination in the United States and the geographical grouping of refusals resulting in outbreaks.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Children exempted from school immunization requirements (vaccine rejection measures) are at increased risk of measles and whooping cough and may infect others who are too young to be vaccinated, cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons or were vaccinated, but did not have a sufficient immune response.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Doctors can play a crucial role in parental decision-making.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Health care providers are cited as the most frequent source of information on immunization by parents, including parents of unvaccinated children.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Although some doctors have interrupted or considered interrupting their relationship with patients who reject vaccines, the Bioethics Committee of the American Academy of Pediatrics advises against this and recommends that doctors treat vaccine rejection by respectfully listening to parents' concerns and discussing the risks of non-vaccination.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccines are one of the most effective tools available to prevent infectious diseases and their complications and sequelae.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: High immunization coverage has resulted in a dramatic decline in vaccine-preventable diseases, particularly in many high- and middle-income countries.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The reduction in the incidence of vaccine-preventable disease often leads to a public perception that the severity of the disease and its susceptibility to it have decreased.1 At the same time, public concern about actual or perceived adverse events associated with vaccines has increased.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: This increase in the level of concern often results in an increase in the number of people who reject vaccines1,2.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In the United States, policy interventions, such as immunization requirements for school admission, have contributed to high vaccine coverage and a record or near record minimum level of vaccine-preventable disease levels.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The immunity of herds, induced by high vaccination rates, has played an important role in reducing or eliminating the continuous endemic transmission of several diseases, thus benefiting the community as a whole, in addition to the person vaccinated.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Recent concerns of parents about vaccine safety problems, such as an alleged association between vaccines and autism, although not supported by a credible set of scientific evidence,3-8 have led an increasing number of parents to refuse to vaccinate their children or delay their vaccination.9.10 The main measure of vaccine rejection in the United States is the proportion of children who are exempt from school immunization requirements for non-medical reasons.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: There has been an increase in state rates of non-medical exemptions from immunization requirements.11 In this article, we reviewed the evidence base for school immunization requirements, explored the determinants of the refusal to vaccinate, and discussed the individual and community risks of vaccine preventable diseases associated with the refusal to vaccinate.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Evolution of immunization needs in the United States

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccination was introduced in the United States in the early 19th century.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Shortly thereafter, in 1809, in Massachusetts, the first U.S. law requiring vaccination against smallpox was passed to prevent and control frequent outbreaks of smallpox that had significant economic and health consequences.12-14 Later, other states enacted similar legislation.13 Despite the challenges inherent in establishing a reliable and safe vaccine delivery system, vaccination was widely accepted as an effective tool to prevent smallpox in the mid-19th century, and the incidence of smallpox declined between 1802 and 1840.15 In the 1850s, “irregular doctors, advocates of unorthodox medical theories,”16 led to the challenges of vaccination.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccination consumption declined, and smallpox reappeared considerably in the 1870s15s.Many states passed new vaccination laws, while other states began enforcing existing laws.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Increased law enforcement often led to increased opposition to vaccination.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Several states, including California, Illinois, Indiana, Minnesota, Utah, West Virginia, and Wisconsin, repealed mandatory vaccination laws.15 Many other states retained them.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a landmark 1905 case, Jacobson v. Massachusetts, which has since served as the basis for public health laws, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the right of states to pass and enforce mandatory vaccination laws.17 In 1922, when deciding a case filed by a girl excluded from a public school (and later from a private school) in San Antonio, Texas, the Supreme Court considered that school immunization requirements were constitutional.18 Since then, the courts have generally supported the power of states to enact and implement immunization requirements.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In 1969, a total of 17 states had laws requiring children to be vaccinated against measles before entering school, and 12 states had legal requirements for vaccination against the six diseases for which routine immunization had been carried out.13 During the 1970s, efforts were made to strengthen and strictly enforce immunization laws.12.13 During measles outbreaks, some state and local health officials excluded students who did not meet immunization requirements from school, resulting in a minimal negative reaction, rapid improvement in local coverage and control of outbreaks.19.22 Efforts by the public health community and other immunization advocates to increase coverage of measles vaccine among school-age children resulted in the implementation of immunization requirements for all vaccines and the introduction of these requirements in states that did not yet have them.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In the early 1980s, all 50 states had school immunization needs.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Recent immunization needs in schools

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Because immunization laws are state-based, there are substantial differences in requirements across the country.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Requirements from one State to another differ in terms of school grades covered, vaccines included, processes and authority used to introduce new vaccines, reasons for exemptions (medical reasons, religious reasons, philosophical or personal beliefs) and procedures for granting exemptions.23

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: State immunization laws contain provisions for certain exemptions.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: As of March 2008, all states allowed medical exemptions from school immunization requirements, 48 states allowed religious exemptions, and 21 states allowed exemptions based on philosophical or personal beliefs.23 Several states (New York, Arkansas, and Texas) have recently expanded eligibility for exemptions.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Secular and geographic trends in refusal to get vaccinated

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Between 1991 and 2004, the average state rate of non-medical exemptions increased from 0.98 to 1.48%.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The increase in exemption rates was not uniform.11 The exemption rates for States that allowed only religious exemptions remained at approximately 1 per cent between 1991 and 2004; however, in States that allowed exemptions for philosophical or personal beliefs, the average exemption rate increased from 0.99 to 2.54 per cent.11

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Like any average, the average exemption rate presents only part of the picture, as the geographical cluster of non-medical exemptions can lead to local accumulation of a critical mass of susceptible children that increases the risk of outbreaks.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: There is evidence of significant geographical heterogeneity in non-medical exemption rates between and within states.24 For example, in the period 2006-2007, the state-wide non-medical exemption rate in Washington was 6 per cent; however, the county-level exemption rate ranged from 1.2 to 26.9 per cent (Figure 1).25 In a spatial analysis of Michigan's exemption data according to census treaties, 23 statistically significant groups of increased exemptions were identified.26 Similar heterogeneity has been identified in exemption rates in Oregon27 and California (unpublished data).

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The reasons for the geographical grouping of exemptions from school vaccination requirements are not fully understood, but may include characteristics of the local population (e.g. cultural issues, socio-economic status or educational level), beliefs of local health-care providers and opinion leaders (e.g. clergy and politicians), and coverage of local media.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The factors known to be associated with exemption rates are heterogeneity in school policies28 and the beliefs of school staff responsible for meeting immunization requirements29.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Instead of rejecting vaccines, some parents delay the vaccination of their children.30-32 Many parents follow new vaccination schedules proposed by individual physicians (rather than those developed by expert committees with members representing multiple disciplines).32.33 Most new schedules involve administering vaccines for a longer period than that recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices and the American Academy of Pediatrics or not administering some vaccines.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Individual risk and vaccine rejection

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: 34.35 In a retrospective cohort study based on national surveillance data from 1985 to 1992, children with exemptions were 35 times more likely to get measles than non-exempt children (relative risk, 35; 95% confidence interval [CI], 34-37).34 In a retrospective cohort study conducted in Colorado, based on data for the years 1987 to 1998, children with exemptions, compared to unvaccinated children, were 22 times more likely to have had measles (relative risk, 22.2; 95% CI, 15.9-31.1) and almost six times more likely to have had whooping cough (relative risk, 5.9; 95% CI, 4.2-8.2).35 The above data indicated that the lower incidence of measles and mumps was related to the existence and application of immunization requirements for school admission.12,36-38.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The consequences of late vaccination compared to vaccine rejection have not been studied in detail.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: However, it is known that the risk of vaccine-preventable diseases and the risk of sequelae of vaccine-preventable diseases are not constant throughout childhood.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Young children are often at increased risk for infectious disease-related diseases and deaths, and delays in vaccination may leave them vulnerable to age at high risk of contracting a number of vaccine-preventable diseases.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In addition, new vaccination schedules that recommend vaccinations over a longer period may exacerbate health inequalities, as parents with a high socio-economic level are more likely to carry out additional visits required under alternative schedules than parents with a low socio-economic level.39

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Grouping of Vaccine Denials and Community Risk

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Multiple studies have shown an increase in the local risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographical aggregation of people who refuse to get vaccinated.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In Michigan, a significant overlap between geographical groups of non-medical exemptions and pertussis groups was documented.26 The proportion of probabilities of a census tract included in a pertussis group was also included in a group of exemptions was 2.7 (95% CI, 2.5 to 3.6) after adjustment for demographic factors.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In Colorado, the incidence of measles and pertussis at the county level in vaccinated children from 1987 to 1998 was associated with the frequency of exemptions in that county.35 At least 11 per cent of non-exempt children who acquired measles were infected by contact with an exempt child.35 In addition, school outbreaks in Colorado were associated with higher exemption rates; the average exemption rate among schools with outbreaks was 4.3 per cent, compared with 1.5 per cent in schools that did not have an outbreak (P=0.001).35

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: High vaccine coverage, particularly at the community level, is extremely important for children who cannot be vaccinated, including children who have medical contraindications for vaccination and those who are too young to be vaccinated.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: These groups are often more susceptible to complications from infectious diseases than the general population of children and depend on the protection provided by the vaccination of children in their surroundings40-42.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The refusal to vaccination and the recent increase in measles cases

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Measles vaccination has been highly successful in controlling a disease that previously contributed to significant morbidity and mortality.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In the United States, the number of reported cases decreased from an average of 500,000 per year in the pre-vaccination era (reported cases were considered as a fraction of the estimated total of over 2 million) to an average of 62 cases per year between 2000 and 2007.43-45 Between 1 January 2008 and 25 April 2008, there were five measles outbreaks and a total of 64 reported cases.45 All but one persons with measles were not vaccinated or had no immunization tests.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Of the 21 cases of children and adolescents in the eligible age group (16 months to 19 years) for a known reason of non-vaccination, 14 or 67 per cent had obtained a non-medical exemption and the 10 school-age children had obtained a non-medical exemption.45 Thirteen cases occurred in children too young to be vaccinated, and in more than one third of the cases (18 of 44) in a known transmission environment the disease was acquired in a health-care centre.45

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases often begin among people who refuse to get vaccinated, spread rapidly among non-vaccinated populations and also spread to other subpopulations.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: For example, of the four outbreaks with discrete index cases (an outbreak occurred through multiple imports) reported from January to April 2008, three out of every four cases of index occurred in people who had refused to be vaccinated for personal beliefs; the vaccination status of the remaining cases could not be verified.45,46 In the State of Washington, a recent outbreak of measles occurred between 12 April 2008 and 30 May 2008, affecting 19 cases.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: All persons with measles were not vaccinated with the exception of the last case, a person who had been vaccinated.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Of the other 18 cases, 1 was an infant who was too young to be vaccinated, 2 were under 4 years old and the remaining 15 were of school age (unpublished data).

column2: Who rejects vaccines and why

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Based on data from the National Immunization Survey for the period 1995-2001, Smith et al.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: They compared the characteristics of children aged 19 to 35 months who did not receive any (unvaccinated) vaccine with the characteristics of those who were partially (unvaccinated) vaccinated.47 Compared to vaccinated children, unvaccinated children were more likely to be male, white, from higher-income households, to have a married mother with a university education and to live with four or more children.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: 47 Other studies have shown that children who are not vaccinated are likely to belong to families who intentionally refuse vaccinations, while children who are under-vaccinated may not have received some vaccinations due to health-care-related factors or sociodemographic characteristics48-51.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a case-control study of the knowledge, attitudes and beliefs of the parents of exempt children compared to the parents of vaccinated children, respondents assessed their views on the vulnerability of their children to specific diseases, the severity of these diseases, and the effectiveness and safety of specific vaccines available to them.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Composite scores were created on the basis of these vaccine-specific responses.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Compared to the parents of vaccinated children, a significantly higher number of parents of exempted children thought that their children had low susceptibility to disease (58% versus 15%, P<0.05), that the severity of the diseases was low (51% versus 18%, P<0.05), and that the efficacy and safety of vaccines was low (54% versus 17% for efficacy and 60% versus 15% for safety, P<0.05 for both comparisons).52 In addition, parents of exempted children were more likely than parents of vaccinated children to have providers offering complementary or alternative medical care and to obtain information from the Internet and groups opposed to immunization aspects.52

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Other studies have also reported the importance of parents' concerns about vaccine safety when they decide not to be vaccinated.53-56 A national parental survey from 2001 to 2002 showed that although only 1% of respondents thought that vaccines were unsafe, their children were nearly three times more likely to be out of date in recommended vaccines than the children of parents who thought vaccines were safe.54 In a case-control study with a national sample, underimmunization was associated with negative perceptions of vaccine safety (probability index, 2.0; 95% CI, 1.2 to 3.4.55 And in another case-control study, Bardenheier et al.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Although concerns about the overall safety of the vaccine did not differ between the parents of vaccinated children and the parents of unvaccinated or unvaccinated children, more than half of the case and control parents expressed concern about the safety of the vaccine to their child's healthcare provider.57 In addition, parents of unvaccinated or unvaccinated children were more likely to believe that children received too many vaccines.57

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The role of health care providers

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Physicians and other health professionals play a crucial role in parental decision-making with regard to immunization.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Parents, including parents of unvaccinated children, cite health-care providers as the most frequent source of information on vaccination.52

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a study of the knowledge, attitudes and practices of primary care providers, a high proportion of those caring for children whose parents had refused to get vaccinated and those caring for properly vaccinated children had favourable views on vaccines.58 However, those caring for unvaccinated children were less likely to have confidence in the safety of vaccines (probability ratio, 0.37; 95% CI, 0.19-0.72) and less likely to perceive vaccines as beneficial to individuals and communities.58 In addition, there was overlap between the unfavourable views of doctors on vaccines and the likelihood that they would have had children who were not vaccinated in their practice.58

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: There is evidence that health care providers have a positive overall impact on parental decision-making regarding vaccination of their children.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a study by Smith et al., parents who reported that their immunization decisions were influenced by their child's health care provider were nearly twice as likely to consider safe vaccines as parents who said their decisions were not influenced by the provider.59

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In focus group discussions, several parents who were not sure to vaccinate their child were willing to discuss their immunization concerns with a health care provider and wanted the provider to provide information relevant to their specific concerns.56 These findings highlight the critical role that doctors can play in explaining the benefits of immunization and addressing parents' concerns about their risks.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Doctors' Response to Refusal to Vaccinate

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: 60.61 In a national survey of members of the American Academy of Pediatrics, nearly 40 per cent of respondents said they would not provide care to a family that rejected all vaccines, and 28 per cent said they would not provide care to a family that rejected some vaccines.61

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The Academy’s Bioethics Committee advises not to interrupt attention to families who decline vaccinations and has recommended that pediatricians “ honestly share what is and what is not known about the risks and benefits of the vaccine in question.”62 The committee also recommends that doctors address the denial of the vaccine by respectfully listening to parents’ concerns, explaining the risk of non-immunisation, and discussing specific vaccines that are of greatest concern to parents.62 The committee advises against more serious measures in most cases: “The continued refusal should be respected after proper discussion unless the child is at significant risk of serious harm (e.g., as could occur during an epidemic).

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Only then should state agencies participate to nullify parental discretion on the basis of medical negligence.”62

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Regulatory determinants of vaccine denial

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Immunization requirements and enforcement policies vary considerably among States; these variations have been associated with exemption rates at the state level.11.63 For example, it has been shown that the complexity of procedures for obtaining exemption is inversely associated with exemption rates.63 In addition, between 1991 and 2004, the average annual incidence of pertussis was almost twice as high in States with administrative procedures that facilitated the acquisition of exemptions as in those States that made it difficult11.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: One possible way to balance individual rights and the greater public good with regard to vaccination would be to institute and expand administrative controls.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: For example, a model law proposed for Arkansas suggested that parents applying for non-medical exemptions should be advised on the dangers of refusing vaccination.64

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: States also differ in compliance with recommendations regarding age-appropriate coverage of children under 2 years of age.65 Immunisation requirements in schools ensure completion of pre-school education, but do not have a direct impact on the timeliness of vaccination among pre-school children.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: However, there is some evidence that school immunization laws have an indirect effect on preschool vaccine coverage.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: For example, the chickenpox vaccine was introduced in the United States in 1995 and has played an important role in reducing the incidence of chickenpox.66 In 2000, States that had implemented compulsory vaccination against chickenpox at school had coverage among children aged 19 to 35 months above the average for all states.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Having an immunization requirement may be an indicator of the effectiveness of a state's immunization program, but the effect of school-based requirements on coverage among preschoolers cannot be completely ruled out.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Conclusions

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The rejection of the vaccine not only increases the individual risk of disease, but also increases the risk for the entire community.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: As a result of substantial progress in reducing vaccine-preventable diseases, the memory of several infectious diseases has faded away from public awareness and the risk-benefit calculation seems to have changed in favour of perceived risks of vaccination in the minds of some parents.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The main reasons for the rejection of the vaccine in the United States are parents' perceptions and concerns about vaccine safety and a low level of concern about the risk of many vaccine-preventable diseases.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: To maintain the enormous benefits of immunization for society, greater efforts will be needed to educate the public about those benefits and to increase public confidence in the systems we use to monitor and ensure vaccine safety.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Since doctors influence parental decision-making, it is important that they understand the benefits and risks of vaccines and provide for questions that parents may have about safety.

column2: There are several sources of vaccine information that should be useful to both doctors and parents (e.g. Appendix 1 of the fifth edition of Vaccines, edited by Plotkin et al.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Notice a prenup – mandatory or not?

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: A prenup is a document that is usually made before or at the beginning of a marriage, with the purpose of producing effects on the division of property.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: The prenup agreement is a very common practice and mostly comes into force at the time of legal separation or divorce.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Its aim is to ensure that spouses/futures agree on a certain division of property, before a potentially conflicting situation occurs that may arise at the time the marriage disintegrates.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Looking at some signs of prenup agreement would be a good idea, as it serves the purpose of taking a look at what a prenup is like.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: There are many samples of free prenup or online templates to look at and help you decide if any of them are right for you while saving on the extra cost of a prenup.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Engaged people often face the difficult situation of signing the prenup.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Looking at the prenup arrangement of the sample can help you decide whether this is an option that works for you or otherwise.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Alternatively, there are also several prenup agreements that offer both pre-marriage and living together agreements that can be easily customized.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: An online prenup will save a lot of time and money.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: An online prenup covers situations in which both parties have already received independent legal advice or in which both parties have decided not to receive any legal advice.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: However, make sure that you and your spouse are equally willing to sign a prenup.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: For example, according to the Texas prenup agreement, a prenup agreement is legally inapplicable if one of the spouses did not voluntarily sign it.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: It would also be helpful if you take a look at some “how to write a prenup” checklist.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Also, do some research and go through some notarized agreement guidelines.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: How much does a prenup cost?

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: There is no simple answer to the question, “How much does it cost to get a prenup?” Factors influencing the cost of the prenup agreement are the location, reputation and experience of the prenup lawyer and the complexity of the deal.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Often interested parties want to know, how long it takes to get a prenup.

column2: It depends on the customers and their problems.

column2: Benefits of a Notarized Prenup Agreement at the Beginning of Your Marriage

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: You wonder how to get a prenup?

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Making the prenup agreement with the help of an experienced prenup lawyer, at the beginning of a union is the most advisable thing, as it ensures that the parties reach an agreement and helps facilitate future separation procedures, at a time when an agreement on financial aspects would otherwise be very difficult to imagine.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: However, this does not mean that the existence of a prenup will completely eliminate any conflict concerning the division of assets.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Although disagreements often arise, it remains useful for this transition to be more direct.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: One of the issues of the premarital agreement that arise quite frequently in relation to the correct and valid conclusion of a premarital agreement is whether a premarital agreement must be notified by the spouses in order for such agreement to be legally binding and to have effect.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: In other words, is the notarization of a prenup mandatory for its validity?

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: The short answer is no.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: The premarital agreement is not a notarial document, so there is no obligation per se to note it.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: However, this does not mean that the agreement is not notified in certain situations.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: For example, when the prenup agreement, when dividing the property between the spouses, also refers to a transfer of immovable property, it is highly recommended that the document be notarized.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Moreover, given the scope of the process of notarization of the form of prenup agreement, the notarization of a premarital agreement also helps to hinder the challenge of its validity later.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: The notary public bears witness to the direct signature of a document that verifies the identity of the signatories and tries to note any red flags that suggest that the parties are not acting freely or as a right.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: If a document is concluded before a notary public, it is increasingly difficult for one of the signatories to state at a later point that he was not present during the signature, that he was forced or unable to give his consent.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Therefore, although it is not mandatory, notarization is encouraged when obtaining a prenup agreement.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: If the spouses notice the prenup agreement, it is likely to be binding in court and produce the intended effects.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Although it is unlikely to succeed, the challenge of a signature results in longer divorce proceedings and leads to delays in the personal and financial situation of the spouses.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Adding an element of conflict to an already difficult and controversial process causes even more tension and tension in a relationship that is already disturbed.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: A common question is, will a notarial agreement be kept in court?

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: The answer is that it carries a reasonable amount of weight and can be persuasive in court, but it's not something you can depend on completely.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: What may happen in the absence of a notarial prenup

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: Failure to sign the prenup agreement could open the door to one of the spouses to try to ignore or circumvent the aspects initially agreed upon in relation to financial rights, expectations or claims.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?
column2: The challenge to the identity of a signatory is one of the ways to ensure that the agreement becomes useless.

column1: Should we support pre-marital property notarization?

column1: Should we embrace globalization?

column1: Should we embrace globalization?
column2: The literature that analyzes the free trade economy is extremely rich with extensive work done on the theoretical and empirical effects.

column1: Should we embrace globalization?
column2: Although it creates winners and losers, the broad consensus among economists is that free trade is a big and unequivocal net gain for society [ref].

column1: Should we embrace globalization?
column2: In a 2006 survey of 83 US economists, 87.5% agree that the US should eliminate tariffs and other barriers to trade and 90.1% disagree with the suggestion that the US should restrict employers from outsourcing work to foreign countries [ref].

column1: Should we embrace globalization?
column2: Citing Harvard economics professor N. Gregory Mankiw, Few propositions command as much consensus among professional economists as open world trade increases economic growth and raises living standards [ref].

column1: Should we embrace globalization?
column2: In a study of leading economists, none disagreed with the notion that freer trade improves productive efficiency and offers consumers better choices, and in the long run these gains are much greater than any effect on employment [ref].

column1: Should we embrace globalization?
column2: Most economists would agree that, although the increase in scale yields could mean that some industry could be established in a geographical area without any strong economic reason derived from comparative advantage, this is no reason to argue against free trade because the absolute level of production enjoyed by both winners and losers will increase with the winner gaining more than the losers, but both earning more than before at an absolute level.

column1: Should we embrace globalization?
column2: In the book The End of Poverty, Jeffrey Sachs discusses how many factors can affect a country's ability to enter the world market, including government corruption; legal and social disparities based on gender, ethnicity or caste; diseases such as AIDS and malaria; lack of infrastructure (including transportation, communications, health and trade); unstable political landscapes; protectionism; and geographical barriers [ref].

column1: Should we embrace globalization?
column2: Jagdish Bhagwati, former UN adviser on globalization, argues that, although there are obvious problems with development too fast, globalization is a very positive force that drives countries out of poverty by causing a virtuous economic cycle associated with faster economic growth [ref].

column1: Should we embrace globalization?
column2: However, economic growth did not necessarily mean poverty reduction; indeed, both could coexist.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: How Online Sales Impact on the Local Economy: Good and Bad

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: With Small Business Saturday a few days away, local companies have the opportunity to gain the attention and business of their target audiences.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Thanks to the meteoric increase in online shopping, you may need it.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Consider these online shopping statistics:

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Sixty-nine percent of Americans have bought something online.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Between 4 and 10 percent of retail sales occur online.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: A quarter of adults in the country buy something online at least once a month.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: During the 2018 holiday season, $126 billion was spent on online shopping in this country.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: All these purchases are purchases that are not being made in a brick and mortar store.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: And that means that all these purchases are having a measurable impact on the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Is that bad news impacting local businesses?

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Reality is a little more complex.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online shopping can remove taxes from the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Perhaps the biggest negative impact online sales have on the economy is that they reduce the amount of sales taxes that the state collects and other local taxes that cities and counties collect.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Not all online retailers charge the appropriate sales tax or other local taxes for items customers buy in their online stores.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: As a result, residents of a state cannot pay sales taxes on online purchases they would have paid if they had made the same purchase at a brick and mortar store.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: This loss of income is measurable.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: In 2012, Indiana lost $195 million in tax revenue from sales to online purchases, according to the University of Tennessee.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: This number is almost certainly higher now that the popularity of online sales has skyrocketed.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: In an attempt to reduce these losses, Indiana passed a law in 2017, which came into effect in October 2018, requiring retailers who earn at least $100,000 in sales in Indiana or who serve at least 200 Indiana residents in a year to collect sales taxes on online purchases.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: However, this law does not affect smaller companies.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: It also does not apply to local taxes and therefore does not completely close the tax gap caused by online purchases.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online sales make it difficult for brick and mortar retailers to compete.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Because many online retailers do not charge their customers sales tax, their purchases cost less.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: A 7 percent charge on a small purchase could be just a few cents or dollars, but the difference can add up to larger purchases.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: In addition, when customers are pinching pennies or doing a lot of shopping, such as during holidays, saving sales taxes can be important to them.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: As a result, brick and mortar stores that have to collect appropriate taxes sometimes have more difficulty competing with online retailers that do not add these taxes to the cost of their items.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: When customers choose to go online instead of going to a brick and mortar store to save money, they restrict the ability of the local company to grow.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online shopping takes money out of the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: The last negative impact online shopping has on the local economy is to get money out of that economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: For example, if a customer buys a Christmas gift from Amazon instead of a local business, that money goes to the national retailer instead of the buyer community.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: This loss of income can restrict the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Less money comes to local businesses, which means they do less hiring.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Less hire means less money flowing into the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Less money flowing into the local economy means fewer jobs and less money available for residents to spend.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: They then spend less money locally, leading to a vicious circle that can keep communities from growing.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online shopping isn't all bad.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: As with any story, there are two sides.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: While online shopping can be removed from the local economy, it can also contribute to it in certain ways.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: The key is for local companies to enter the online market.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: The main disadvantages of online shopping seem to occur when consumers make such purchases to domestic companies rather than to local businesses.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: For example, a local business is likely to charge appropriate taxes for online purchases, and fall under Indiana law that requires certain businesses to charge sales taxes for online purchases.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Similarly, when consumers shop online for local businesses, that money still goes to the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Instead of losing money to non-local entities, the local economy still receives the money from these online purchases, as these purchases continue to be made from local businesses.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: The advantage of all this is that local companies must strive to create a vibrant online presence.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online shopping isn't going anywhere.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Its convenience means that it is likely to continue to grow in popularity.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Instead of fighting this new reality, local companies can accept it.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Through digital marketing, they can build a website and advertising campaigns that put them in front of their target audiences.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: It is not impossible to compete against large companies.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: It simply requires an intelligent online strategy, and an expert digital marketing company like Distinct Web Design.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: As the holiday shopping season takes off, consider taking advantage of the good that an online presence can do, both for your business and for your local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Then get to Distinct Web Design.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: We can help you identify digital marketing strategies that will best enable your business to thrive, online and offline
