column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Importance of the Threatened Species Act

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The Threatened Species Act (ESA), adopted in 1973, was enacted to halt the rapid loss of plant and animal life.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Often known as the “crown jewel” of our nation’s environmental laws, ESA has been responsible for saving many species previously on the brink of extinction, including the bald eagle, the gray wolf, and California’s sea otter.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: ESA is the only environmental legislation to date that does not require a cost-benefit analysis before taking action, making it particularly effective.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Once a species is declared threatened or endangered, the ESA ensures that it will be protected and that every effort will be made to contribute to its recovery.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The Threatened Species Act is not only our strongest environmental law, but it also articulates a noble vision.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In it, for the first time in the history of the world, legislators of a great nation said they would do everything possible to prevent the extinction of any species within their border.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Environmental importance

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Healthy ecosystems depend on plant and animal species as their foundation.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: When a species is endangered, it is a sign that the ecosystem is slowly falling apart.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Each species that is lost triggers the loss of other species within its ecosystem.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Human beings depend on healthy ecosystems to purify our environment.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Without healthy forests, grasslands, rivers, oceans and other ecosystems, we will not have clean air, water or land.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: If we allow our environment to become contaminated, we run the risk of our own health.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Unfortunately, only about 5% of known plant species have been tested for medicinal uses and there are thousands of plant species that have not yet been identified.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Tens of thousands of Americans die each year from diseases for which there is no known cure.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The cures for these diseases may eventually come from plants, so we must protect all species before they are lost forever from the medicine cabinet of nature.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: With a firm understanding of the importance of endangered and endangered species, we need to make sure that they are protected.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Unfortunately, species are sliding through cracks in ESA.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: And an experimental drug derived from the saliva of Gila monsters, a poisonous lizard in the southwest of the United States and parts of Mexico, has been found to help people with type 2 diabetes keep their blood sugar at healthy levels, according to Michelle Magee, MD, director of the MedStar Diabetes Institute.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: They are the first sign of serious environmental problems.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: There is no better way to track the health of our ecosystems and the species that live in them than through living organisms.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: For example, freshwater mussels that filter ocean water are often the first to point to pollution problems, and the decline in the population of pilgrims hawks alerted the world to the dangers of DDT.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: These creatures often serve as canaries in the coal mine, alerting us to dangerous environmental conditions when we would never realize otherwise.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: However, Nick Bostrom's orthogonal thesis argues against this, and instead affirms that, with some technical warnings, more or less any level of intelligence or optimization power can be combined with more or less any final goal.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

This means that if a human society was highly motivated (perhaps at gunpoint) to design an efficient real-world algorithm with goal G, and it was given a million years to do so along with huge amounts of resources, training and knowledge about AI, it must fail; that there can be no reinforcement learning pattern that trains a highly efficient real-world intelligence to follow goal G; and that there can be no evolutionary or environmental pressure that evolves highly efficient real-world intelligences following goal G [ref].

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: Comparative advertising or advertising warfare is an advertisement in which a particular product or service specifically mentions a competitor by name for the express purpose of demonstrating why the competitor is inferior to the product calling it [ref].

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: Also known as a knockout copy, it is vaguely defined as advertising where “the advertised brand is explicitly compared to one or more competing brands and the comparison is obvious to the public”[3].

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: This should not be confused with parody advertisements, in which a fictitious product is advertised in order to have fun in the particular advertisement, nor should it be confused with the use of a minted mark in order to compare the product without actually naming a real competitor.

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: In the United States, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) defined comparative advertising as “announcement comparing alternative brands in objectively measurable attributes or prices, identifying the alternative brand by name, illustration or other distinctive information”.[4] This definition was used in the Gillette Australia Pty Ltd v Energizer Australia Pty Ltd [ref] case.

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: Similarly, the Australian Legal Council recently suggested that comparative advertising refers to “advertising that includes the reference to the brand of a competitor in a manner that does not impute ownership on the brand to the advertiser”[6].

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Pros and cons of compulsory gymnastics class in public schools

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Supporters of compulsory gymnastics programs argue that physical education classes have a wide range of benefits.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: According to the National Association for Sport and Physical Education, physical education classes help children develop fine and thick motor skills, learn to cooperate and work as a team, reduce stress, and improve self-confidence and self-esteem.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: In addition, supporters argue that public schools have a responsibility to encourage children to enjoy a healthy and active lifestyle, especially since an increasing number of American youth are obese.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Activities that promote muscle strength, cardiovascular endurance, and flexibility, they argue, can help reverse the tendency of American children to gain weight.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Subsequently, some school leaders were left without a clear answer in the debate.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Should physical fitness classes be required to meet the requirements of a school's curriculum?

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Expounding more on the subject, MSNBC also analyses an important study of the physical education programs carried out by Cornell University.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: The study, based on information from 37,000 secondary school students' responses to surveys of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, reveals that most students do not believe that gymnastics class is effective.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: This has led almost every state to create and pass new bills to reform the physical education programs of public schools.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Unfortunately, while many states have increased the time students spend in gym class, Cornell's study found that adding 200 more minutes of time to gym class each week did not produce substantial changes.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Even adding 200 more minutes a week, studies showed that boys generally performed only 7.5 minutes of more activity per day, while girls only participated in the activity 8 additional minutes per week.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Trying to explain these disappointing results, Cornell’s senior professor of policy analysis and management states: “The rest of the gym’s extra time is probably spent being sedentary—most likely standing idle while playing sports such as softball or volleyball that do not require constant movement.” Cornell’s results hit a family nerve, as a study of fitness classes in Texas primary schools also found that most students spent inactive class time; specifically, the data suggested that students were only doing exercise or movement for about 3 minutes throughout the class period.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: As reported in USA Today, what would benefit children the most are periods of rigorous physical activity that cause them to break a sweat.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: High-energy games like tag and dodgeball are great examples of activities that have little downtime.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: At a minimum, elementary-aged children should do 30 minutes of moderate exercise per day.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: High school and high school students should receive 45 minutes of exercise per day.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: And about half of that time must be spent in activities such as those mentioned above that achieve the acceleration of the heart.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Despite the results, the principal professor of Cornell study does not necessarily believe that gymnastics classes should be banned in public school, arguing: “We are not saying that schools should get rid of (physical education), but “there must be a significant change in the curriculum.”

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: While many of the country's gymnastics classes may not be acting at the highest levels, supporters of physical education aim to highlight the potential of reform, as well as the achievements that many public schools have achieved.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: In examining the changing policies of physical education, it is important to understand how gymnastics classes can be modernized in public schools.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: While running around and jumping used to be a basic element of many physical education classes, many schools have diversified their options to reflect a more modern take in gym class.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Schools offer instruction in traditional team sports and games such as flag football and red rover, but they also emphasize healthy eating habits, the benefits of lifting weights and offer unique bowling experiences to fly-to- kayak fishing.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: By offering more intriguing physical activities for students, many public schools are reporting positive feedback from their students and community members.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Many physical education leaders are advocating a complete paradigm shift in the area of physical education and well-being.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Elizabeth Spletzer, a highly experienced fitness instructor who currently coordinates the University of Minnesota's Bachelor of Physical Education Program, strives to teach future fitness teachers the various learning benefits that children get from physical activity.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: Instead of seeing gym class as just a physical activity, reformers like Spletzer want others to understand the psychosocial benefits of exercise, including improving self-esteem, better behavior, and decreasing cases of depression and stress.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: There are also academic benefits.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: According to a New York Times report, students who are physically active have better attention and focus, better problem-solving skills, better working memory, and an overall improvement in reading and math scores.

column1: Should physical education be compulsory
column2: In fact, the academic benefits that students get from physical activity during the school day seem to outweigh the benefits of increasing class time in subjects such as reading and mathematics.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Delete standardized tests for university admissions

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: A new study by the National Association for College Admission Counseling provides evidence that optional testing policies (a variety of policies that allow students not to present standardized test scores such as SAT or GRE during the admission process) can help universities improve their diversity without sacrificing academic quality.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The study found that schools that do not require SAT/ACT saw an increase in the enrolment of underrepresented color students compared to comparable institutions that require a test score and that admitted students who did not present grades were as likely to graduate as admitted students who did.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The report also found that the average high school grades (GPA) were a better predictor of success at the GPA university than the test results for non-presenters.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: In January 2018, more than 1,000 universities and colleges have stopped requiring SAT or ACT qualifications for undergraduate candidates.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The conversation also extends to the graduate level, where institutions are dealing with whether to use standardized tests, what and how.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: In particular, the Inclusive Graduate Education Network and the Alliance for Multifielding, Inclusive Graduate Admissions, are promoting and studying the impact of inclusive holistic review practices.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: These projects are also exploring what factors of an application are most important for admission to graduate school versus success in graduate school.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: (Full disclosure: I am affiliated with IGEN and FRIEND, but the opinions here are mine and do not necessarily represent these projects or anyone affiliated with them.)

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The NACAC report contrasts with Measuring Success: Tests, Degrees and the Future of University Admissions, a recent book published by scholars linked to the testing industry, which argues that optional testing policies are ineffective in increasing diversity or do not do better than similar institutions that require such testing.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Unfortunately, this debate eludes a serious issue: the urgent need to seek solutions beyond the ways in which selective admissions to universities take place today.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: We need to pay attention to the deeper purposes to which the selection criteria serve, and for whom.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The use of standardized evidence in admissions disproportionately excludes people of color and other marginalized groups.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The truth is that overwhelming research has shown that performance in these tests is better at predicting demographic characteristics such as class, gender, and race than educational outcomes.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: This disproportionately excludes racial minorities, women and low-income people from targeted schools.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: For many higher education professionals, these tests are simply the most efficient and common metric for evaluating students.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: But efficiency can no longer be an excuse to maintain a faulty system.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The only outcome we can expect from that course of action is the efficient maintenance of the status quo of inequality.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The creators and advocates of standardized testing promote the notion that equality requires us to use a unique metric to evaluate everyone in the same way.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: But a common tool cannot fairly measure the potential of people who have been given different opportunities in life.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Our limited resources must be redirected towards finding better ways to achieve equitable results, which will require compensating for prior inequality of opportunities and resources.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: In January 2018, more than 1,000 universities and colleges have stopped requiring SAT or ACT qualifications for undergraduate candidates.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: From academics to politicians, people mistakenly believe that standardized tests are better at predicting college results, such as grades and graduation, than they really are.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: This uncritical belief in the current admissions system allows those who have benefited to feel that they gained their position completely on their own.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Indeed, our success is a combination of our efforts, opportunities and resources to make the most of both.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: This lost faith also makes us complicit in excluding those who have not had our same privileges.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Even if standardized tests predict the achievements perfectly, they would do so on the basis of the accumulated resources that have helped privileged children to reach the levels of success they have by the time they take the test.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: These differences in testing do not represent the potential of students to learn and achieve.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: As documented by Jerome Karabel in The Chosen: The Hidden History of Admission and Exclusion at Harvard, Yale and Princeton, standardized tests played a twisted role in the history of admissions to selective institutions.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Selection criteria such as SAT/ACT and GRE come from historical actions that have deliberately defined merit to exclude students based on their social identity, including religious affiliation.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Add to that history generations of schools that lack sufficient funding and other racial and class-based discrimination that continue to hamper the achievements of racially minority and low-income students.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Accepting any “predictive” measures that perpetuate these inequalities, even indirectly, is detrimental to today’s communities of color and poor people and deprives future generations of their potential.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: In order for the United States to rise to its full potential, we need to stop rejecting students from the possibilities of higher education only because their background has not provided them with the same opportunities or resources to take advantage of previous opportunities.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: To this end, researchers such as Estela Bensimon highlight the responsibility of our educators and educational institutions to better care for marginalized students to support the success of all students.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: So, how do we move forward?

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Some research suggests that holistic review may be better at judging a student's potential given the context of their previous experiences.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Many highly selective institutions such as Harvard, Yale and Columbia already claim to practice a holistic revision version because of the support of the United States Supreme Court for this approach in affirmative action cases.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: However, these options are widely used and researched together with standardized tests that produce disparate results based on race and class.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: We have inherited a society built on grave injustices, and perpetuated them by intentional acts and failures in repairing what has been done.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Higher education, from university to graduate school, can provide opportunities and resources for people to maximize their potential, but only if we make access to it more equitable.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The only way forward is to enact policies and practices, especially in education, that are corrective and redistributive.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The time has come to put an end to the perpetuation of systemic inequality through institutional practices that seem facially neutral, but have an uneven impact by race and class.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Ending the use of standardized tests at all levels of admission is one of the ways we can do it.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The economy of the Olympic Games

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Introduction

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The Olympic Games have evolved dramatically since the first modern games were held in 1896.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: In the second half of the 20th century, both the accommodation costs and the revenues generated by the show grew rapidly, causing controversy over the burdens borne by host countries.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: A growing number of economists argue that the short- and long-term benefits of hosting games are at best exaggerated and at worst non-existent, leaving many host countries with large debts and maintenance obligations.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: On the other hand, many argue that the Olympic committees should reform the bidding and selection process to encourage realistic budget planning, increase transparency and promote sustainable investments in the public interest.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The Rio de Janeiro games of 2016 highlighted the ongoing debate on the costs and benefits of hosting such a mega-event.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: More than a year later, the city continues to struggle with the debt contracted, the costs of maintaining abandoned facilities, poorly equipped public services, and the increase in crime as candidate cities for future games either withdraw their offers or reduce their plans.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: When did the costs of hosting the games become a concern?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: For much of the 20th century, the celebration of the Olympic Games was a manageable burden for host cities.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The events were held in developed countries, either in Europe or in the United States, and in the pre-television era, the hosts did not expect to make any profits.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Instead, the games were publicly funded, with these advanced countries better positioned to assume costs due to their larger economies and more advanced infrastructure.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The 1970s marked a turning point, writes Andrew Zimbalist, author of Circus Maximus: The Economic Gamble Behind Hosting the Olympics and the World Cup.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The games were growing rapidly, with the number of participants in the Summer Olympics almost doubling and the number of events increasing by a third during the 1960s.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Each Olympiad since 1960 has seen great cost overruns [PDF].

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The killing of protesters in the days leading up to the 1968 Mexico City Games and the fatal assault on Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Games tarnished the image of the Olympic Games, and public scepticism about taking over the debt to host the games grew.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: In 1972, Denver became the first and only host city elected to reject its Olympic Games after voters passed a referendum rejecting additional public spending for the games.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The 1976 Montreal Olympic Games symbolized the fiscal risks of hosting.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The projected cost of $124 million was billions below the real cost, largely due to construction delays and cost overruns for a new stadium, saddled city taxpayers with about $1.5 billion in debt that took nearly three decades to pay.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: As a result, in 1979 Los Angeles was the only city to run for the 1984 Olympic Games, allowing it to negotiate exceptionally favourable conditions with the International Olympic Committee (IOC).

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Most importantly, L.A. was able to rely almost entirely on existing stadiums and other infrastructure rather than promising new facilities to attract the IOC selection committee.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: This, combined with a sharp jump in television revenue, made L.A. the only city to turn a profit into the Olympic Games, ending with an operating surplus of $215 million.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The success of L.A. led to an increase in the number of cities bidding, from two for the 1988 games to twelve for the 2004 games.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: This allowed IOC to choose cities with the most ambitious and expensive plans.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: In addition, as researchers Robert Baade and Victor Matheson point out, tenders from developing countries more than tripled after 1988.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Countries like China, Russia and Brazil have been eager to use the games to demonstrate their progress on the world stage.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: However, these countries invested massive sums to create the necessary infrastructure.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Costs amounted to more than $45 billion for the 2008 Beijing Summer Games, more than $50 billion for the Sochi Winter Games in 2014, and $20 billion for Rio de Janeiro in 2016.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: For the 2018 games, the local government in Pyeongchang, South Korea, will pay a ticket of nearly $13 billion, compared to the $7 billion originally projected.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: These costs have given rise to new skepticism, and several cities have withdrawn their offers for the 2022, 2024 and 2028 games on cost concerns.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Oslo and Stockholm withdrew from their 2022 offers as they realized that the costs would be higher than originally estimated.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Boston withdrew from consideration for the Games of 2024, with its mayor saying that “he refused to mortgage the future of the city.” Finalists of 2024, Budapest, Hamburg and Rome, also withdrew, leaving only Los Angeles and Paris.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: In an unprecedented movement, given the lack of candidates, the IOC chose venues 2024 and 2028 simultaneously in 2017, with Paris and Los Angeles taking turns hosting.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: What costs do cities incur to host games?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Cities must first invest millions of dollars in evaluating, preparing and submitting an offer to IOC.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The cost of planning, hiring consultants, organizing events and travel required is constantly falling between $50 million and $100 million.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Tokyo spent up to $150 million on its failed 2016 offer, and about half for its successful 2020 offer, while Toronto decided that it could not afford the $60 million it would have needed for a 2024 offer.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Once a city is chosen to host, it has almost a decade to prepare for the influx of athletes and tourists.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The Summer Games are much larger, attracting hundreds of thousands of foreign tourists to see more than ten thousand athletes compete at about three hundred events, compared to less than three thousand athletes competing at about a hundred events during the Winter Games.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The most immediate need is the creation or improvement of highly specialized sports facilities such as cycling trails and ski slopes, the Olympic Village and a place large enough to host the opening and closing ceremonies.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: More general infrastructure, especially housing and transport, is also often needed.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The IOC requires that the cities hosting the summer games have a minimum of 40,000 hotel rooms available, which in the case of Rio required the construction of 15,000 new hotel rooms.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: There is a need to improve or build roads, train lines and airports.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: In total, these infrastructure costs range from $5 billion to more than $50 billion.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Many countries justify such expenditures in the hope that expenditures will survive the Olympic Games.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Operational costs constitute a smaller but still significant part of the budget for the host Olympics.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The debt service that remains after hosting the games can overburden public budgets for decades.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: But while some in Sochi see unused stadiums and overbuilt facilities as waste, other residents argue that the games boosted spending on roads, water systems and other public goods that would otherwise not have happened.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: How are benefits compared to costs?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles were the only games to produce a surplus, largely because the city was able to rely on the existing infrastructure.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: As housing costs have skyrocketed, income covers only a fraction of expenditures.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: The 2008 Beijing Olympics generated $3.6 billion in revenue, compared to more than $40 billion in costs, and the 2012 London Games generated $52 billion compared to $18 billion in costs.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: In addition, much of the revenue is not allocated to the host: the IOC maintains more than half of all television revenues, usually most of the money generated by the games.

column2: Impact studies conducted or commissioned by host governments prior to the games often argue that holding the event will provide an important economic boost by creating employment, attracting tourists and boosting overall economic production.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: In a study of the 2002 Salt Lake City Games, for example, Matheson, along with economists Robert Baumann and Bryan Engelhardt of the College of the Holy Cross of Massachusetts, found a short-term boost [PDF] of seven thousand additional jobs, about one tenth of the number promised by officials, and no long-term increase in employment.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: As explained in a study by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the jobs created by the construction of the Olympic Games are often temporary, and unless the host region suffers from high unemployment, jobs mainly go to workers who are already employed, which reduces the impact on the economy in general.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: (Only 10 percent of the forty-eight thousand temporary jobs created during the 2012 London Olympic Games were stopped, according to the study).

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Economists have reached a consensus that the Olympic Games need reforms to make them more affordable.

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?

column1: Should we fight for the Olympics?
column2: Apart from that, many economists argue, any city planning to host should ensure that games fit into a broader strategy to promote development that survives the Olympic festivities.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: An acquisition of AI is a hypothetical scenario in which artificial intelligence (AI) becomes the dominant form of intelligence on Earth, with computers or robots that effectively take control of the planet away from the human species.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Possible scenarios include replacing the entire human workforce, taking over by a superintelligent AI, and the popular notion of a robot uprising.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Some public figures, such as Stephen Hawking and Elon Musk, have advocated for the investigation of precautionary measures to ensure that future super-intelligent machines remain under human control [ref].
